evidence.pdf_reference: (2) excitation of the doped nanocrystallites in the visible; (3) photosensitization of titania by visible excitation of the dye and electron transfer into the conduction band of the semiconductor 48,49.The extent of photosensitization of titania by BB has been studied in separate experiments using pure titania catalyst (cf.Ref. 6) and it was found to offer an important contribution to BB photodegradation.However, it does not seem to play a crucial role in the present analysis.In all three studied cases,

powder was obtained from the original sol by vacuum evaporation of the solvent followed by calcination, as in the case of films themselves. Photodegradation experiments were carried out in a small cylindrical batch reactor containing about 4 ml of an aqueous solution of the organic substance to be photodegraded.Inside the reactor we fit the glass slide with titania film in such a way that all part of the slide bearing catalyst was immersed in the solution.The reactor was illuminated by a 450 W xenon

Thin films of pure or doped nanocrystalline titania have been deposited on glass slides by using a sol-gel procedure, in the presence of surfactant Triton X-100, which acts as template of the nanostructure.Fe 3 , Cr 3 and Co 2 were used as dopants while the doping extended in a broad domain from very low to very high levels.The photocatalytic efficiency of pure or doped titania was tested for discoloration of an aqueous solution of Basic Blue 41.The presence of dopants resulted in a progressive loss of

wafers show that the employed synthesis procedure produces nanocrystalline titania with a relatively large concentration of surface hydroxyl groups.The marked photocatalytic efficiency of these films, which has been previously established and which will also emerge in the present data is, among other reasons, also due to the high surface hydroxyl content.As already said, hydroxyl groups scavenge photogenerated holes thus preventing electron-hole recombination, at the same time producing highly oxidant
